comment.author: 18753752@N00
comment._content: Here is Ms. Noyes dressed as Lady Liberty in another LOC photo: www.loc.gov/shop/index.php?action=cCatalog.showItem&c...

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: I think this must be an early photo of mystery writer Frances Noyes Hart. The Noyes family owned the Washington Star, so her photo showing up in a newspaper even before she published any of her books would not be surprising.

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: In regard to captainslack's comment above: the LOC photo linked there does not depict Frances Noyes, but dancer Florence Fleming Noyes.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for pointing out potential connections to other Library of Congress photographs -- and potential identity confusions! If you want to see even more of the story on identity confusions (not Florence Noyes and not Lady Liberty according to information researchers gave us), see the image and revised title in the Prints and Photographs Online Catalog: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ppmsc.00032

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: The photo of Hedwig Reicher in costume as Columbia is all over the Internet, identified as Florence F. Noyes as Liberty. Everybody must be relying on the misleading Bain caption. The LOC does have a decent photo of Florence Fleming Noyes, but the photo with Hedwig Reichert isn't big enough, even in its TIFF version, to be able to make a comparison between the picture of Ms. Noyes and the background figures in the Reichert photo to determine if she is among them. The LOC also has another photo of Frances Noyes, but it is in the Arnold Genthe collection which has not been made available online in large versions. From the thumbnail (use the terms "Noyes, Miss" on the Prints & Photographs search page), it appears to be the same woman at the wheel of the car in the photo above, though somewhat gussied up. It occurs to me that, since Frances Noyes served as an ambulance driver during WWI (her first published book was about her war experiences- available for download in several formats here at the Internet Archive), the photo above may depict her at about that time- perhaps 1917-1918. The right-hand-drive car suggests that the photograph might have been taken in England.

comment.author: 82967752@N00
comment._content: The buildings in the background don't look English at all.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Frances Noyes Hart (1890-1943) was an American writer whose short stories were published in Scribner's magazine, the Saturday Evening Post, the Ladies' Home Journal. Her father was the head of the Associated Press. She married Edward H. Hart in 1921. If this image is from 1913, she would have been 23 years old when she embarked on a tour of the world with Martha Bowers and Thomas W. Bowers. It was covered in the Washington Post. The Bowers are most likely the passengers in the car. I started a Wikipedia entry on her: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frances_Noyes_Hart And one on her father: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Brett_Noyes

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Richard, I noticed that you put her father's name above her photo on Wikipedia.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The photo is from the Bain News Agency's 1912 photostream.
